intro: Suaeda turgida, commonly known as saltbush, is a halophyte shrub adapted to saline environments. It belongs to the family Amaranthaceae and is native to arid and semi-arid regions of the Middle East, Central Asia, and parts of Africa. The plant has succulent, fleshy leaves that store water, and its small, greenish flowers are clustered in dense inflorescences. Suaeda turgida is often found growing on saline soils and in coastal areas, where it plays a role in stabilizing dunes. Its ability to tolerate high salinity makes it an important species in ecological restoration projects.
